page.title: 17RIVER TORRIDGE
page.content: The River Torridge flows half a mile north of Black Torrington, from west to east. It is crossed by Black Torrington Bridge, built for carts and packhorses in medieval times, and by Coham Bridge. The lush meadows of its flood plain are one third of a mile across, bounded by steep wooded slopes to the south and gentler rising grassland to the north. The Torridge has long been renowned as a salmon fishery but recent catches have dramatically declined, probably due to pollution. Corn was formerly ground at Kingsley Mill, close to Black Torrington Bridge, and remains of leats and weirs can be found. Otters can very occasionally be seen, while kingfishers, wagtails and a profusion of wild flowers can be found along its banks. The river is too shallow to be of any use for transport.
